Commutators and squares in free groups
Sucharit Sarkar
Abstract Let F2 be the free group generated by x and y . In this article,
we prove that the commutator of xm and y n is a product of two squares if
and only if mn is even. We also show using topological methods that there
are infinitely many obstructions for an element in F2 to be a product of
two squares.
AMS Classification 20F12; 57M07
Keywords Commutators, free groups, products of commutators

1

Introduction

In any group G, the commutator of two elements g and h is a product of three
squares, namely,
2
ghg−1 h−1 = g2 g−1 h h−2 .
Let [g, h] denote the commutator of g and h. It is natural to ask whether [g, h]
can be written as a product two squares. Since the subgroup generated by g and
h in G is a quotient of the free group on two generators, the answer would be
in the affirmative if we knew that the commutator of the generators of the free
group on two generators can be written as a product of two squares. However,
if F2 is the free group on two generators x and y , a theorem of Lyndon and
Newman [2] states that the commutator [x, y] is not a product of two squares.
Here, we give the following generalisation of their theorem. Further, the method
of our proof extends to give infinitely many obstructions to an element being
the product of two squares.
Theorem 1.1 [xm , y n ] is a product of two squares in F2 = hx, yi if and only
if mn is even.
In the case when m = n = 1 this gives the theorem of Lyndon and Newman.
Our methods also give a proof of the following theorem of Akhavan-Malayeri [1].

Theorem 1.2 (Akhavan-Malayeri) [x, y]2n+1 is not a product of two squares
in F2 = hx, yi.
We first reformulate the question in terms of products of conjugate elements.
Lemma 1.3 An element g ∈ F2 can be expressed as a product g = a2 b2 of
two squares if and only if g can be expressed as a product g = c(d−1 cd) of two
conjugate elements.
Proof This follows immediately from the relation a2 b2 = (ab)(b−1 (ab)b).
The following statement underlines the importance of the previous lemma.
Lemma 1.4 Suppose g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] is of the form g = ab with a and b conjugate
in F2 . Then a, b ∈ [F2 , F2 ].
Proof Let g 7→ ḡ be the abelianisation homomorphism F2 → Z2 . Then as
g ∈ [F2 , F2 ], 0 = ḡ = ā + b̄ = 2ā where the last equality holds as a and b are
conjugate. Thus, ā = b̄ = 0 which implies that a, b ∈ [F2 , F2 ].
The heart of our proof lies in constructing a group homomorphism φ : [F2 , F2 ] →
Z which is invariant under conjugacy action of F2 , i.e., φ(a) = φ(g−1 ag) for all
a ∈ [F2 , F2 ] and g ∈ F2 . The construction of our homomorphism is topological.
If an element g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] is a product of two squares, then we shall see that
φ(g) is even. This gives a criterion to decide whether g is the product of two
squares. The theorem of Lyndon and Newman follows from this. We shall
extend this to stronger criteria for an element in [F2 , F2 ] to be a product of two
squares.

2

The homomorphism φ

We construct a homomorphism φ : [F2 , F2 ] → Z which is invariant under the
conjugacy action of F2 . The theorem of Lyndon and Newman follows from the
properties of this homomorphism.
Let K be the wedge of two circles. Then π1 (K) = F2 . Let K̃ be the universal
abelian cover of K . This is the cover corresponding to the subgroup [F2 , F2 ]
of F2 . We can identify K̃ with a subcomplex of R2 whose vertices are Z2 and
edges join (i, j) either to (i + 1, j) or to (i, j + 1).

Let X and Y denote the edges from (0, 0) to (1, 0) and (0, 1) respectively.
Under the group Z2 of deck transformations each edge is the image of X or Y .
Denoting the group of deck transformations multiplicatively and taking x and
y to be the generators, we see that all edges are of the form xi y j X or xi y j Y
with i, j ∈ Z.
Consider the simplicial homology of K̃ . We shall first define a homomorphism
θ : Z1 (K̃) → Z from the 1-cycles to the integers which is invariant under deck
transformations. The homomorphism φ will be defined in terms of this.
Observe that, using the above notation, the simplicial chains of K̃ are of the
form α = Pα (x, y)X + Qα (x, y)Y with Pα (x, y) and Qα (x, y) Laurent polynomials. Let fα(y) = Pα (1, y). The action by a deck transformation xk y l takes
α = Pα (x, y)X + Qα (x, y)Y to xk y l α = xk y l Pα (x, y)X + xk y l Qα (x, y)Y .
Further, for a cycle α, it is easy to see that fα (1) = Pα (1, 1) = 0. We define
the homomorphism θ by
θ(α) = fα′ (1).
Lemma 2.1 θ : Z1 (K̃) = H1 (K̃) → Z is invariant under the group of deck
transformations.
Proof It suffices to show that θ(xα) = θ(α) = θ(yα). The first equality is
obvious as fxα = fα . The second follows as

Here we used the fact that for a cycle fα (1) = 0.
As K̃ is a 1-complex, this can be viewed as a homomorphism, also denoted
θ , from H1 (K̃) to Z. Using this, we define φ : [F2 , F2 ] → Z. Namely, given a
curve γ in K representing an element g ∈ [F2 , F2 ], take a lift γ̃ of γ to K̃ . This
represents an element in homology, and we let φ(g) = θ(γ̃). This is independent
of the lift chosen as different lifts are related by deck transformation, and θ is
invariant under deck transformations.
We need some properties of φ.
Lemma 2.2 φ(g) = φ(hgh−1 ) for all g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] and h ∈ F2 .
Proof The elements of g and hgh−1 of [F2 , F2 ] can be represented by curves
that have lifts in K̃ that differ by deck transformations. As deck transformations leave θ invariant, φ(g) = φ(hgh−1 ).

Lemma 2.3 Suppose g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] is a product of two squares. Then φ(g) is
even.
Proof By Lemma 1.3 we can write g = hk with h and k elements of [F2 , F2 ]
that are conjugate in F2 . We have φ(g) = φ(h)+φ(k) = 2φ(h) as φ is invariant
under conjugation.
Consider the lift to K̃ of a curve γ representing [x, y] in K . This lift gives
the cycle α = (1 − y)X + (x − 1)Y and, hence φ([x, y]) = fα′ (1) = −1. Thus,
φ is non-trivial. Moreover, by the above lemma [x, y] is not a product of two
squares.
We now prove our extension of the result of Lyndon and Newman, one half of
which is an extension of the above argument.
Proof of Theorem 1.1 Take a curve γ representing [xm , y n ]. We see that
the lift of this starting at the origin gives the chain
α = (1 + x + . . . xm−1 )(1 − y n )X + (1 + y + * * * + y n−1 )(xm − 1)Y
and hence φ([xm , y n ]) = −mn. Hence if [xm , y n ] is the product of two squares,
mn is even.
Conversely, if mn is even, we assume without loss of generality that m is even.

We have constructed a homomorphism φ on [F2 , F2 ] that is invariant under
conjugacy. Now [F2 , F2 ] is the smallest normal subgroup of F2 containing
[x, y]. Therefore, any such homomorphism is determined by its value on [x, y].
In particular, if we make the analogous construction taking g(x) = Qα (x, 1)
in place of f (y) and define ψ(α) = g′ (1), we have ψ = −φ as we can see by
evaluating on [x, y].

599

Further criteria

So far we have one criterion for an element in [F2 , F2 ] to be a product of two
squares, namely, if g is a product of two squares then φ(g) is even. If φ(g) = 0
(which implies ψ(g) = 0), there are other criteria. These are obtained by
constructing homomorphisms φ2 and ψ2 on appropriate subgroups of G =
[F2 , F2 ] which are even on elements that are products of two squares.
We first need some lemmas. Let G1 denote the kernel of φ. Since φ is conjugacy
invariant, G1 is a normal subgroup of F2 . Let H1 = ker(ψ) = G1 .
Lemma 3.1 Suppose φ(g) = 0 and g = ab with a and b conjugate. Then
a, b ∈ G1 .
Proof As φ is conjugacy invariant, 0 = φ(g) = 2φ(a).
We need an elementary property of derivatives of polynomials.
Lemma 3.2 Let f (t) be a Laurent polynomial with integer coefficients. Then
f k (t) is divisible by k!.
Proof The k th derivative of tn is divisible by n(n − 1) * * * (n − k + 1) which
in turn is divisible by k!. The result follows.
Now we can define two homomorphisms φ2 and ψ2 from H1 = G1 to Z by
φ2 (g) = fα′′ (1)/2 and ψ2 = gα′′ (1)/2 with α as before. The proof that these are
well defined and conjugacy invariant is exactly as in the previous section.
Continuing in this manner, we let G2 = ker(φ2 ) and H2 = ker(ψ2 ). We
inductively define groups Hk and Gk and homomorphisms φk : Gk−1 → Z and

Lemma 3.3 The homomorphisms φk and ψk are invariant under the action

Lemma 3.4 If g ∈ Gk (respectively g ∈ Hk ) is a product of two squares, then
φk (g) (respectively ψk ) is even.

Thus, we have infinitely many obstructions to an element being the product
of two squares. More precisely, let g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] be an element. We evaluate
φ(g) = −ψ(g). There are three possibilities: φ(g) = 0, φ(g) is even or φ(g) is
odd. In case φ(g) is odd, we know that g is not a square. If it is even but nonzero, we cannot deduce any further obstructions. In the case when φ(g) = 0,
we have additional homomorphisms φ2 and ψ2 which can be applied to g to
get an odd or even number. This process can be continued inductively.

4

Some examples

We have constructed in the previous section two sequences of obstructions to
an element g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] being a product of two squares, based on the homomorphisms φk and ψk . We shall show that all these are non-trivial in the sense
that there are elements for which the first k − 1 homomorphisms vanish and
the k th is odd.
On the other hand, in the case when f (y) = 0 and g(x) = 0 as polynomials, all
our homomorphisms vanish. We shall construct examples where this happens.
Our examples are based on the observation that the associations γ → Pγ and
γ → Qγ are module homomorphisms over the ring of Laurent polynomials in
variables x and y , from H1 (K̃) to Laurent polynomials. Further, we have a
surjection from the commutator subgroup [F2 , F2 ] = π1 (K̃) to its abelianisation
H1 (K̃).
Proposition 4.1 For any k > 1, there is an element g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] such that
φj (g) = 0 for all j < k , φk (g) = −1 and ψj (g) = 0 for all j .
Proof Let g be an element whose image in H1 (K̃) is γ = (y − 1)k−1 α, where
α denotes the class of [x, y] in H1 (K̃). As Pα = −(y − 1), and the associations
γ → Pγ and γ → Qγ are module homomorphisms, it follows that Pγ = −(y−1)k
and Qγ = (y − 1)k−1 (x − 1).
Now fγ (y) = Pγ (1, y) = −(y − 1)k and gγ (x) = Qγ (x, 1) = 0 and hence
φj (g) = 0 for all j < k , φk (g) = −1 and ψj (g) = 0 for all j .
Recall that we consider succesively the homorphisms φk (and ψk ), with φk+1
defined if φk vanishes. The first non-zero φk gives a criterion for an element
being the product of two squares. We see in the next example that there are
elements in [F2 , F2 ] for which all the φk vanish.

Proposition 4.2 There is an element g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] such that φj (g) = 0 =
ψj (g), for all j .
Proof We take g whose image in H1 (K̃) is γ = (x − 1)(y − 1)α. Then, using
the notation of the above proposition, we see that fγ (y) = 0 and gγ (x) = 0,
and hence φj (g) = 0 = ψj (g), for all j .

5

Factorisation and another criterion

The above example suggests a variant of our criteria.
Proposition 5.1 Let g ∈ [F2 , F2 ] be an element with α the corresponding
cycle in H1 (K̃). Suppose (x−1)k (y −1)l divides Pα (x, y) with quotient h(x, y).
If g is a product of two squares then h(1, 1) is even.
Proof We have seen that if g is the product of two squares, it is the product
of two conjugates c and d. Let Ab denote the abelianisation map [F2 , F2 ] →
H1 (K̃). Then Ab(g) = Ab(c) + Ab(d). As c and d are conjugate (in F2 ), they
differ by a deck transformation of K̃ . Equivalently, c and d differ by the action
by conjugation of the abelianisation F2 /[F2 , F2 ] = Z2 on the commutator subgroup [F2 , F2 ]. This action has been identified with multiplication by Laurent
polynomials.
Hence, for some integers m, n ∈ Z, we have Ab(d) = xm y n Ab(c). It follows
that Ab(g) = (xm y n + 1)Ab(c) and hence (1 + xm y n ) divides Pα .
Now the ring of Laurent polynomials over Z in x and y is a unique factorisation
domain, and x − 1 and y − 1 are prime elements. Further, they do not divide
E(x, y) = (1 + xm y m ) as E(1, 1) 6= 0. Thus, E(x, y) divides h(x, y). As
E(1, 1) = 2, h(1, 1) is even.
